hints.content: Let's look at how Amy and Greg solve the problem.

###Amy's way

Amy multiplied $\blueD7 \times \purpleC6$ to find the total number of desks. 



[[☃ image 1]]

$\blueD7 \times \purpleC6$ is the same as $\blueD7$ groups of $\purpleC6$.

So, Amy is correct.

options.alt: An array of circles arranged in 7 rows of 6 circles each. A line separates each row. Along the left side of the array, the rows are numbered 1 to 7. Along the top of the array, the columns are numbered 1 to 6. !

hints.content:
###Greg's way

Greg multiplied $\purpleC{6} \times \blueD{7}$ to find the total number of desks. 



[[☃ image 1]]

We can also group the array as $\purpleC6$ columns with $\blueD7$ dots each. 

The expression $\purpleC{6} \times \blueD{7}$ can also represents the array.

So, Greg is correct.

[[☃ explanation 1]]

options.explanation:
Yes! In a rectangular array, the $\blueD{\text{number of rows}}$ is always the same as the $\blueD{\text{size of the columns}}$. The $\purpleC{\text{number of columns}}$ is always the same as the $\purpleC{\text{size of the rows}}$.

In multiplication, we can switch the factors without changing our total.

$\begin{align}
\blueD{\text{ Number of rows}}\times\purpleC{\text{ size of the rows}} = \greenD{ \text{ total}}\\\\
\purpleC{\text{Number of columns}}\times\blueD{\text{ size of columns}} = \greenD{ \text{ total}}
\end{align}$

We call that pattern the **commutative property of multiplication**.

options.alt: An array of circles arranged in 6 columns of 7 circles each. A line separates each column. Along the left side of the array, the rows are numbered 1 to 7. Along the top of the array, the columns are labeled 1 to 6. !

hints.content: Both Amy and Greg are correct.

question.content:
Music class has $7$ rows of desks.  There are $6$ desks in each row.

Amy multiplied $7\times6$ to find the total number of desks. 

Greg multiplied $6\times7$ to find the total number of desks. 

**Who is correct?**

[[☃ radio 2]]
